reason.tex: %text A Vector is a measurable entity which not only has a magnitude (or quantity) but also a direction. An example would be{\bf speed, in a particular direction} e.g. $13(km/h)$ headed north by north-west. In a coordinate system, a vector in $3D$ space is expressed like this, % \begin{align} \ora{A}=\vector{3}{-1}{2} \end{align}\\ %text Vector $\ora{A}$, when broken into components is $3$ units along the x-axis, $1$ unit along the negative y-axis and 2 units along the z-axis where $i$, $j$ and $k$ are $1$ unit vectors along the three axes. The magnitude of vector $\ora{A}$ is given by, % \begin{align} |\ora{A}|=\sqrt{3^2+(-1)^2+2^2}=\sqrt{14} \end{align}\\ %text The magnitude of a vector is always a positive value even if the vector itself may be negative, for e.g.$\ora{a}=\vector{-5}{}{}$, but $|\ora{a}|=5$. A{\bf unit vector} always has magnitude $1$. %
